4""" 

5`matplotlib.pyplot` is a state-based interface to matplotlib. It provides 

6an implicit, MATLAB-like, way of plotting. It also opens figures on your 

7screen, and acts as the figure GUI manager. 

8 

9pyplot is mainly intended for interactive plots and simple cases of 

10programmatic plot generation:: 

11 

12 import numpy as np 

13 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

14 

15 x = np.arange(0, 5, 0.1) 

16 y = np.sin(x) 

17 plt.plot(x, y) 

18 plt.show() 

19 

20The explicit object-oriented API is recommended for complex plots, though 

21pyplot is still usually used to create the figure and often the Axes in the 

22figure. See `.pyplot.figure`, `.pyplot.subplots`, and 

23`.pyplot.subplot_mosaic` to create figures, and 

24:doc:`Axes API </api/axes_api>` for the plotting methods on an Axes:: 

25 

26 import numpy as np 

27 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt 

28 

29 x = np.arange(0, 5, 0.1) 

30 y = np.sin(x) 

31 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

32 ax.plot(x, y) 

33 plt.show() 

34 

35 

36See :ref:`api_interfaces` for an explanation of the tradeoffs between the 

37implicit and explicit interfaces. 

38""" 

39

164@overload 

165def _copy_docstring_and_deprecators( 

166 method: Any, 

167 func: Literal[None] = None 

168) -> Callable[[Callable[_P, _R]], Callable[_P, _R]]: ... 

169 

170 

171@overload 

172def _copy_docstring_and_deprecators( 

173 method: Any, func: Callable[_P, _R]) -> Callable[_P, _R]: ... 

174 

175 

176def _copy_docstring_and_deprecators( 

177 method: Any, 

178 func: Callable[_P, _R] | None = None 

179) -> Callable[[Callable[_P, _R]], Callable[_P, _R]] | Callable[_P, _R]: 

180 if func is None: 

181 return cast('Callable[[Callable[_P, _R]], Callable[_P, _R]]', 

182 functools.partial(_copy_docstring_and_deprecators, method)) 

183 decorators: list[Callable[[Callable[_P, _R]], Callable[_P, _R]]] = [ 

184 _docstring.copy(method) 

185 ] 

186 # Check whether the definition of *method* includes @_api.rename_parameter 

187 # or @_api.make_keyword_only decorators; if so, propagate them to the 

188 # pyplot wrapper as well. 

189 while hasattr(method, "__wrapped__"): 

190 potential_decorator = _api.deprecation.DECORATORS.get(method) 

191 if potential_decorator: 

192 decorators.append(potential_decorator) 

193 method = method.__wrapped__ 

194 for decorator in decorators[::-1]: 

195 func = decorator(func) 

196 _add_pyplot_note(func, method) 

197 return func 

198 

199 

200_NO_PYPLOT_NOTE = [ 

201 'FigureBase._gci', # wrapped_func is private 

202 '_AxesBase._sci', # wrapped_func is private 

203 'Artist.findobj', # not a standard pyplot wrapper because it does not operate 

204 # on the current Figure / Axes. Explanation of relation would 

205 # be more complex and is not too important. 

206] 

207 

208 

209def _add_pyplot_note(func, wrapped_func): 

210 """ 

211 Add a note to the docstring of *func* that it is a pyplot wrapper. 

212 

213 The note is added to the "Notes" section of the docstring. If that does 

214 not exist, a "Notes" section is created. In numpydoc, the "Notes" 

215 section is the third last possible section, only potentially followed by 

216 "References" and "Examples". 

217 """ 

218 if not func.__doc__: 

219 return # nothing to do 

220 

221 qualname = wrapped_func.__qualname__ 

222 if qualname in _NO_PYPLOT_NOTE: 

223 return 

224 

225 wrapped_func_is_method = True 

226 if "." not in qualname: 

227 # method qualnames are prefixed by the class and ".", e.g. "Axes.plot" 

228 wrapped_func_is_method = False 

229 link = f"{wrapped_func.__module__}.{qualname}" 

230 elif qualname.startswith("Axes."): # e.g. "Axes.plot" 

231 link = ".axes." + qualname 

232 elif qualname.startswith("_AxesBase."): # e.g. "_AxesBase.set_xlabel" 

233 link = ".axes.Axes" + qualname[9:] 

234 elif qualname.startswith("Figure."): # e.g. "Figure.figimage" 

235 link = "." + qualname 

236 elif qualname.startswith("FigureBase."): # e.g. "FigureBase.gca" 

237 link = ".Figure" + qualname[10:] 

238 elif qualname.startswith("FigureCanvasBase."): # "FigureBaseCanvas.mpl_connect" 

239 link = "." + qualname 

240 else: 

241 raise RuntimeError(f"Wrapped method from unexpected class: {qualname}") 

242 

243 if wrapped_func_is_method: 

244 message = f"This is the :ref:`pyplot wrapper <pyplot_interface>` for `{link}`." 

245 else: 

246 message = f"This is equivalent to `{link}`." 

247 

248 # Find the correct insert position: 

249 # - either we already have a "Notes" section into which we can insert 

250 # - or we create one before the next present section. Note that in numpydoc, the 

251 # "Notes" section is the third last possible section, only potentially followed 

252 # by "References" and "Examples". 

253 # - or we append a new "Notes" section at the end. 

254 doc = inspect.cleandoc(func.__doc__) 

255 if "\nNotes\n-----" in doc: 

256 before, after = doc.split("\nNotes\n-----", 1) 

257 elif (index := doc.find("\nReferences\n----------")) != -1: 

258 before, after = doc[:index], doc[index:] 

259 elif (index := doc.find("\nExamples\n--------")) != -1: 

260 before, after = doc[:index], doc[index:] 

261 else: 

262 # No "Notes", "References", or "Examples" --> append to the end. 

263 before = doc + "\n" 

264 after = "" 

265 

266 func.__doc__ = f"{before}\nNotes\n-----\n\n.. note::\n\n {message}\n{after}" 

267

272# The state controlled by {,un}install_repl_displayhook(). 

273_ReplDisplayHook = Enum("_ReplDisplayHook", ["NONE", "PLAIN", "IPYTHON"]) 

274_REPL_DISPLAYHOOK = _ReplDisplayHook.NONE

278 if matplotlib.is_interactive(): 

279 draw_all()

281 

282def install_repl_displayhook() -> None: 

283 """ 

284 Connect to the display hook of the current shell. 

285 

286 The display hook gets called when the read-evaluate-print-loop (REPL) of 

287 the shell has finished the execution of a command. We use this callback 

288 to be able to automatically update a figure in interactive mode. 

289 

290 This works both with IPython and with vanilla python shells. 

291 """ 

292 global _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK 

293 

294 if _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK is _ReplDisplayHook.IPYTHON: 

295 return 

296 

297 # See if we have IPython hooks around, if so use them. 

298 # Use ``sys.modules.get(name)`` rather than ``name in sys.modules`` as 

299 # entries can also have been explicitly set to None. 

300 mod_ipython = sys.modules.get("IPython") 

301 if not mod_ipython: 

302 _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK = _ReplDisplayHook.PLAIN 

303 return 

304 ip = mod_ipython.get_ipython() 

305 if not ip: 

306 _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK = _ReplDisplayHook.PLAIN 

307 return 

308 

309 ip.events.register("post_execute", _draw_all_if_interactive) 

310 _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK = _ReplDisplayHook.IPYTHON 

311 

312 if mod_ipython.version_info[:2] < (8, 24): 

313 # Use of backend2gui is not needed for IPython >= 8.24 as that functionality 

314 # has been moved to Matplotlib. 

315 # This code can be removed when Python 3.12, the latest version supported by 

316 # IPython < 8.24, reaches end-of-life in late 2028. 

317 from IPython.core.pylabtools import backend2gui 

318 ipython_gui_name = backend2gui.get(get_backend()) 

319 else: 

320 _, ipython_gui_name = backend_registry.resolve_backend(get_backend()) 

321 # trigger IPython's eventloop integration, if available 

322 if ipython_gui_name: 

323 ip.enable_gui(ipython_gui_name) 

324 

325 

326def uninstall_repl_displayhook() -> None: 

327 """Disconnect from the display hook of the current shell.""" 

328 global _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK 

329 if _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK is _ReplDisplayHook.IPYTHON: 

330 from IPython import get_ipython 

331 ip = get_ipython() 

332 ip.events.unregister("post_execute", _draw_all_if_interactive) 

333 _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK = _ReplDisplayHook.NONE 

334 

335 

336draw_all = _pylab_helpers.Gcf.draw_all

358 

359def _get_backend_mod() -> type[matplotlib.backend_bases._Backend]: 

360 """ 

361 Ensure that a backend is selected and return it. 

362 

363 This is currently private, but may be made public in the future. 

364 """ 

365 if _backend_mod is None: 

366 # Use rcParams._get("backend") to avoid going through the fallback 

367 # logic (which will (re)import pyplot and then call switch_backend if 

368 # we need to resolve the auto sentinel) 

369 switch_backend(rcParams._get("backend")) 

370 return cast(type[matplotlib.backend_bases._Backend], _backend_mod) 

371 

372 

373def switch_backend(newbackend: str) -> None: 

374 """ 

375 Set the pyplot backend. 

376 

377 Switching to an interactive backend is possible only if no event loop for 

378 another interactive backend has started. Switching to and from 

379 non-interactive backends is always possible. 

380 

381 If the new backend is different than the current backend then all open 

382 Figures will be closed via ``plt.close('all')``. 

383 

384 Parameters 

385 ---------- 

386 newbackend : str 

387 The case-insensitive name of the backend to use. 

388 

389 """ 

390 global _backend_mod 

391 # make sure the init is pulled up so we can assign to it later 

392 import matplotlib.backends 

393 

394 if newbackend is rcsetup._auto_backend_sentinel: 

395 current_framework = cbook._get_running_interactive_framework() 

396 

397 if (current_framework and 

398 (backend := backend_registry.backend_for_gui_framework( 

399 current_framework))): 

400 candidates = [backend] 

401 else: 

402 candidates = [] 

403 candidates += [ 

404 "macosx", "qtagg", "gtk4agg", "gtk3agg", "tkagg", "wxagg"] 

405 

406 # Don't try to fallback on the cairo-based backends as they each have 

407 # an additional dependency (pycairo) over the agg-based backend, and 

408 # are of worse quality. 

409 for candidate in candidates: 

410 try: 

411 switch_backend(candidate) 

412 except ImportError: 

413 continue 

414 else: 

415 rcParamsOrig['backend'] = candidate 

416 return 

417 else: 

418 # Switching to Agg should always succeed; if it doesn't, let the 

419 # exception propagate out. 

420 switch_backend("agg") 

421 rcParamsOrig["backend"] = "agg" 

422 return 

423 old_backend = rcParams._get('backend') # get without triggering backend resolution 

424 

425 module = backend_registry.load_backend_module(newbackend) 

426 canvas_class = module.FigureCanvas 

427 

428 required_framework = canvas_class.required_interactive_framework 

429 if required_framework is not None: 

430 current_framework = cbook._get_running_interactive_framework() 

431 if (current_framework and required_framework 

432 and current_framework != required_framework): 

433 raise ImportError( 

434 "Cannot load backend {!r} which requires the {!r} interactive " 

435 "framework, as {!r} is currently running".format( 

436 newbackend, required_framework, current_framework)) 

437 

438 # Load the new_figure_manager() and show() functions from the backend. 

439 

440 # Classically, backends can directly export these functions. This should 

441 # keep working for backcompat. 

442 new_figure_manager = getattr(module, "new_figure_manager", None) 

443 show = getattr(module, "show", None) 

444 

445 # In that classical approach, backends are implemented as modules, but 

446 # "inherit" default method implementations from backend_bases._Backend. 

447 # This is achieved by creating a "class" that inherits from 

448 # backend_bases._Backend and whose body is filled with the module globals. 

449 class backend_mod(matplotlib.backend_bases._Backend): 

450 locals().update(vars(module)) 

451 

452 # However, the newer approach for defining new_figure_manager and 

453 # show is to derive them from canvas methods. In that case, also 

454 # update backend_mod accordingly; also, per-backend customization of 

455 # draw_if_interactive is disabled. 

456 if new_figure_manager is None: 

457 

458 def new_figure_manager_given_figure(num, figure): 

459 return canvas_class.new_manager(figure, num) 

460 

461 def new_figure_manager(num, *args, FigureClass=Figure, **kwargs): 

462 fig = FigureClass(*args, **kwargs) 

463 return new_figure_manager_given_figure(num, fig) 

464 

465 def draw_if_interactive() -> None: 

466 if matplotlib.is_interactive(): 

467 manager = _pylab_helpers.Gcf.get_active() 

468 if manager: 

469 manager.canvas.draw_idle() 

470 

471 backend_mod.new_figure_manager_given_figure = ( # type: ignore[method-assign] 

472 new_figure_manager_given_figure) 

473 backend_mod.new_figure_manager = ( # type: ignore[method-assign] 

474 new_figure_manager) 

475 backend_mod.draw_if_interactive = ( # type: ignore[method-assign] 

476 draw_if_interactive) 

477 

478 # If the manager explicitly overrides pyplot_show, use it even if a global 

479 # show is already present, as the latter may be here for backcompat. 

480 manager_class = getattr(canvas_class, "manager_class", None) 

481 # We can't compare directly manager_class.pyplot_show and FMB.pyplot_show because 

482 # pyplot_show is a classmethod so the above constructs are bound classmethods, and 

483 # thus always different (being bound to different classes). We also have to use 

484 # getattr_static instead of vars as manager_class could have no __dict__. 

485 manager_pyplot_show = inspect.getattr_static(manager_class, "pyplot_show", None) 

486 base_pyplot_show = inspect.getattr_static(FigureManagerBase, "pyplot_show", None) 

487 if (show is None 

488 or (manager_pyplot_show is not None 

489 and manager_pyplot_show != base_pyplot_show)): 

490 if not manager_pyplot_show: 

491 raise ValueError( 

492 f"Backend {newbackend} defines neither FigureCanvas.manager_class nor " 

493 f"a toplevel show function") 

494 _pyplot_show = cast('Any', manager_class).pyplot_show 

495 backend_mod.show = _pyplot_show # type: ignore[method-assign] 

496 

497 _log.debug("Loaded backend %s version %s.", 

498 newbackend, backend_mod.backend_version) 

499 

500 if newbackend in ("ipympl", "widget"): 

501 # ipympl < 0.9.4 expects rcParams["backend"] to be the fully-qualified backend 

502 # name "module://ipympl.backend_nbagg" not short names "ipympl" or "widget". 

503 import importlib.metadata as im 

504 from matplotlib import _parse_to_version_info # type: ignore[attr-defined] 

505 try: 

506 module_version = im.version("ipympl") 

507 if _parse_to_version_info(module_version) < (0, 9, 4): 

508 newbackend = "module://ipympl.backend_nbagg" 

509 except im.PackageNotFoundError: 

510 pass 

511 

512 rcParams['backend'] = rcParamsDefault['backend'] = newbackend 

513 _backend_mod = backend_mod 

514 for func_name in ["new_figure_manager", "draw_if_interactive", "show"]: 

515 globals()[func_name].__signature__ = inspect.signature( 

516 getattr(backend_mod, func_name)) 

517 

518 # Need to keep a global reference to the backend for compatibility reasons. 

519 # See https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/issues/6092 

520 matplotlib.backends.backend = newbackend # type: ignore[attr-defined] 

521 

522 # Make sure the repl display hook is installed in case we become interactive. 

523 install_repl_displayhook() 

524 

525 

526def _warn_if_gui_out_of_main_thread() -> None: 

527 warn = False 

528 canvas_class = cast(type[FigureCanvasBase], _get_backend_mod().FigureCanvas) 

529 if canvas_class.required_interactive_framework: 

530 if hasattr(threading, 'get_native_id'): 

531 # This compares native thread ids because even if Python-level 

532 # Thread objects match, the underlying OS thread (which is what 

533 # really matters) may be different on Python implementations with 

534 # green threads. 

535 if threading.get_native_id() != threading.main_thread().native_id: 

536 warn = True 

537 else: 

538 # Fall back to Python-level Thread if native IDs are unavailable, 

539 # mainly for PyPy. 

540 if threading.current_thread() is not threading.main_thread(): 

541 warn = True 

542 if warn: 

543 _api.warn_external( 

544 "Starting a Matplotlib GUI outside of the main thread will likely " 

545 "fail.") 

546 

547 

548# This function's signature is rewritten upon backend-load by switch_backend. 

549def new_figure_manager(*args, **kwargs): 

550 """Create a new figure manager instance.""" 

551 _warn_if_gui_out_of_main_thread() 

552 return _get_backend_mod().new_figure_manager(*args, **kwargs)

565 return _get_backend_mod().draw_if_interactive(*args, **kwargs)

568# This function's signature is rewritten upon backend-load by switch_backend. 

569def show(*args, **kwargs) -> None: 

570 """ 

571 Display all open figures. 

572 

573 Parameters 

574 ---------- 

575 block : bool, optional 

576 Whether to wait for all figures to be closed before returning. 

577 

578 If `True` block and run the GUI main loop until all figure windows 

579 are closed. 

580 

581 If `False` ensure that all figure windows are displayed and return 

582 immediately. In this case, you are responsible for ensuring 

583 that the event loop is running to have responsive figures. 

584 

585 Defaults to True in non-interactive mode and to False in interactive 

586 mode (see `.pyplot.isinteractive`). 

587 

588 See Also 

589 -------- 

590 ion : Enable interactive mode, which shows / updates the figure after 

591 every plotting command, so that calling ``show()`` is not necessary. 

592 ioff : Disable interactive mode. 

593 savefig : Save the figure to an image file instead of showing it on screen. 

594 

595 Notes 

596 ----- 

597 **Saving figures to file and showing a window at the same time** 

598 

599 If you want an image file as well as a user interface window, use 

600 `.pyplot.savefig` before `.pyplot.show`. At the end of (a blocking) 

601 ``show()`` the figure is closed and thus unregistered from pyplot. Calling 

602 `.pyplot.savefig` afterwards would save a new and thus empty figure. This 

603 limitation of command order does not apply if the show is non-blocking or 

604 if you keep a reference to the figure and use `.Figure.savefig`. 

605 

606 **Auto-show in jupyter notebooks** 

607 

608 The jupyter backends (activated via ``%matplotlib inline``, 

609 ``%matplotlib notebook``, or ``%matplotlib widget``), call ``show()`` at 

610 the end of every cell by default. Thus, you usually don't have to call it 

611 explicitly there. 

612 """ 

613 _warn_if_gui_out_of_main_thread() 

614 return _get_backend_mod().show(*args, **kwargs) 

615 

616 

617def isinteractive() -> bool: 

618 """ 

619 Return whether plots are updated after every plotting command. 

620 

621 The interactive mode is mainly useful if you build plots from the command 

622 line and want to see the effect of each command while you are building the 

623 figure. 

624 

625 In interactive mode: 

626 

627 - newly created figures will be shown immediately; 

628 - figures will automatically redraw on change; 

629 - `.pyplot.show` will not block by default. 

630 

631 In non-interactive mode: 

632 

633 - newly created figures and changes to figures will not be reflected until 

634 explicitly asked to be; 

635 - `.pyplot.show` will block by default. 

636 

637 See Also 

638 -------- 

639 ion : Enable interactive mode. 

640 ioff : Disable interactive mode. 

641 show : Show all figures (and maybe block). 

642 pause : Show all figures, and block for a time. 

643 """ 

644 return matplotlib.is_interactive() 

645 

646 

647# Note: The return type of ioff being AbstractContextManager 

648# instead of ExitStack is deliberate. 

649# See https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/issues/27659 

650# and https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/27667 for more info. 

651def ioff() -> AbstractContextManager: 

652 """ 

653 Disable interactive mode. 

654 

655 See `.pyplot.isinteractive` for more details. 

656 

657 See Also 

658 -------- 

659 ion : Enable interactive mode. 

660 isinteractive : Whether interactive mode is enabled. 

661 show : Show all figures (and maybe block). 

662 pause : Show all figures, and block for a time. 

663 

664 Notes 

665 ----- 

666 For a temporary change, this can be used as a context manager:: 

667 

668 # if interactive mode is on 

669 # then figures will be shown on creation 

670 plt.ion() 

671 # This figure will be shown immediately 

672 fig = plt.figure() 

673 

674 with plt.ioff(): 

675 # interactive mode will be off 

676 # figures will not automatically be shown 

677 fig2 = plt.figure() 

678 # ... 

679 

680 To enable optional usage as a context manager, this function returns a 

681 context manager object, which is not intended to be stored or 

682 accessed by the user. 

683 """ 

684 stack = ExitStack() 

685 stack.callback(ion if isinteractive() else ioff) 

686 matplotlib.interactive(False) 

687 uninstall_repl_displayhook() 

688 return stack 

689 

690 

691# Note: The return type of ion being AbstractContextManager 

692# instead of ExitStack is deliberate. 

693# See https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/issues/27659 

694# and https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/27667 for more info. 

695def ion() -> AbstractContextManager: 

696 """ 

697 Enable interactive mode. 

698 

699 See `.pyplot.isinteractive` for more details. 

700 

701 See Also 

702 -------- 

703 ioff : Disable interactive mode. 

704 isinteractive : Whether interactive mode is enabled. 

705 show : Show all figures (and maybe block). 

706 pause : Show all figures, and block for a time. 

707 

708 Notes 

709 ----- 

710 For a temporary change, this can be used as a context manager:: 

711 

712 # if interactive mode is off 

713 # then figures will not be shown on creation 

714 plt.ioff() 

715 # This figure will not be shown immediately 

716 fig = plt.figure() 

717 

718 with plt.ion(): 

719 # interactive mode will be on 

720 # figures will automatically be shown 

721 fig2 = plt.figure() 

722 # ... 

723 

724 To enable optional usage as a context manager, this function returns a 

725 context manager object, which is not intended to be stored or 

726 accessed by the user. 

727 """ 

728 stack = ExitStack() 

729 stack.callback(ion if isinteractive() else ioff) 

730 matplotlib.interactive(True) 

731 install_repl_displayhook() 

732 return stack 

733 

734 

735def pause(interval: float) -> None: 

736 """ 

737 Run the GUI event loop for *interval* seconds. 

738 

739 If there is an active figure, it will be updated and displayed before the 

740 pause, and the GUI event loop (if any) will run during the pause. 

741 

742 This can be used for crude animation. For more complex animation use 

743 :mod:`matplotlib.animation`. 

744 

745 If there is no active figure, sleep for *interval* seconds instead. 

746 

747 See Also 

748 -------- 

749 matplotlib.animation : Proper animations 

750 show : Show all figures and optional block until all figures are closed. 

751 """ 

752 manager = _pylab_helpers.Gcf.get_active() 

753 if manager is not None: 

754 canvas = manager.canvas 

755 if canvas.figure.stale: 

756 canvas.draw_idle() 

757 show(block=False) 

758 canvas.start_event_loop(interval) 

759 else: 

760 time.sleep(interval)

801def xkcd( 

802 scale: float = 1, length: float = 100, randomness: float = 2 

803) -> ExitStack: 

804 """ 

805 Turn on `xkcd <https://xkcd.com/>`_ sketch-style drawing mode. 

806 

807 This will only have an effect on things drawn after this function is called. 

808 

809 For best results, install the `xkcd script <https://github.com/ipython/xkcd-font/>`_ 

810 font; xkcd fonts are not packaged with Matplotlib. 

811 

812 Parameters 

813 ---------- 

814 scale : float, optional 

815 The amplitude of the wiggle perpendicular to the source line. 

816 length : float, optional 

817 The length of the wiggle along the line. 

818 randomness : float, optional 

819 The scale factor by which the length is shrunken or expanded. 

820 

821 Notes 

822 ----- 

823 This function works by a number of rcParams, so it will probably 

824 override others you have set before. 

825 

826 If you want the effects of this function to be temporary, it can 

827 be used as a context manager, for example:: 

828 

829 with plt.xkcd(): 

830 # This figure will be in XKCD-style 

831 fig1 = plt.figure() 

832 # ... 

833 

834 # This figure will be in regular style 

835 fig2 = plt.figure() 

836 """ 

837 # This cannot be implemented in terms of contextmanager() or rc_context() 

838 # because this needs to work as a non-contextmanager too. 

839 

840 if rcParams['text.usetex']: 

841 raise RuntimeError( 

842 "xkcd mode is not compatible with text.usetex = True") 

843 

844 stack = ExitStack() 

845 stack.callback(rcParams._update_raw, rcParams.copy()) # type: ignore[arg-type] 

846 

847 from matplotlib import patheffects 

848 rcParams.update({ 

849 'font.family': ['xkcd', 'xkcd Script', 'Comic Neue', 'Comic Sans MS'], 

850 'font.size': 14.0, 

851 'path.sketch': (scale, length, randomness), 

852 'path.effects': [ 

853 patheffects.withStroke(linewidth=4, foreground="w")], 

854 'axes.linewidth': 1.5, 

855 'lines.linewidth': 2.0, 

856 'figure.facecolor': 'white', 

857 'grid.linewidth': 0.0, 

858 'axes.grid': False, 

859 'axes.unicode_minus': False, 

860 'axes.edgecolor': 'black', 

861 'xtick.major.size': 8, 

862 'xtick.major.width': 3, 

863 'ytick.major.size': 8, 

864 'ytick.major.width': 3, 

865 }) 

866 

867 return stack 

868 

869 

870## Figures ## 

871 

872def figure( 

873 # autoincrement if None, else integer from 1-N 

874 num: int | str | Figure | SubFigure | None = None, 

875 # defaults to rc figure.figsize 

876 figsize: tuple[float, float] | None = None, 

877 # defaults to rc figure.dpi 

878 dpi: float | None = None, 

879 *, 

880 # defaults to rc figure.facecolor 

881 facecolor: ColorType | None = None, 

882 # defaults to rc figure.edgecolor 

883 edgecolor: ColorType | None = None, 

884 frameon: bool = True, 

885 FigureClass: type[Figure] = Figure, 

886 clear: bool = False, 

887 **kwargs 

888) -> Figure: 

889 """ 

890 Create a new figure, or activate an existing figure. 

891 

892 Parameters 

893 ---------- 

894 num : int or str or `.Figure` or `.SubFigure`, optional 

895 A unique identifier for the figure. 

896 

897 If a figure with that identifier already exists, this figure is made 

898 active and returned. An integer refers to the ``Figure.number`` 

899 attribute, a string refers to the figure label. 

900 

901 If there is no figure with the identifier or *num* is not given, a new 

902 figure is created, made active and returned. If *num* is an int, it 

903 will be used for the ``Figure.number`` attribute, otherwise, an 

904 auto-generated integer value is used (starting at 1 and incremented 

905 for each new figure). If *num* is a string, the figure label and the 

906 window title is set to this value. If num is a ``SubFigure``, its 

907 parent ``Figure`` is activated. 

908 

909 figsize : (float, float), default: :rc:`figure.figsize` 

910 Width, height in inches. 

911 

912 dpi : float, default: :rc:`figure.dpi` 

913 The resolution of the figure in dots-per-inch. 

914 

915 facecolor : :mpltype:`color`, default: :rc:`figure.facecolor` 

916 The background color. 

917 

918 edgecolor : :mpltype:`color`, default: :rc:`figure.edgecolor` 

919 The border color. 

920 

921 frameon : bool, default: True 

922 If False, suppress drawing the figure frame. 

923 

924 FigureClass : subclass of `~matplotlib.figure.Figure` 

925 If set, an instance of this subclass will be created, rather than a 

926 plain `.Figure`. 

927 

928 clear : bool, default: False 

929 If True and the figure already exists, then it is cleared. 

930 

931 layout : {'constrained', 'compressed', 'tight', 'none', `.LayoutEngine`, None}, \ 

932default: None 

933 The layout mechanism for positioning of plot elements to avoid 

934 overlapping Axes decorations (labels, ticks, etc). Note that layout 

935 managers can measurably slow down figure display. 

936 

937 - 'constrained': The constrained layout solver adjusts Axes sizes 

938 to avoid overlapping Axes decorations. Can handle complex plot 

939 layouts and colorbars, and is thus recommended. 

940 

941 See :ref:`constrainedlayout_guide` 

942 for examples. 

943 

944 - 'compressed': uses the same algorithm as 'constrained', but 

945 removes extra space between fixed-aspect-ratio Axes. Best for 

946 simple grids of Axes. 

947 

948 - 'tight': Use the tight layout mechanism. This is a relatively 

949 simple algorithm that adjusts the subplot parameters so that 

950 decorations do not overlap. See `.Figure.set_tight_layout` for 

951 further details. 

952 

953 - 'none': Do not use a layout engine. 

954 

955 - A `.LayoutEngine` instance. Builtin layout classes are 

956 `.ConstrainedLayoutEngine` and `.TightLayoutEngine`, more easily 

957 accessible by 'constrained' and 'tight'. Passing an instance 

958 allows third parties to provide their own layout engine. 

959 

960 If not given, fall back to using the parameters *tight_layout* and 

961 *constrained_layout*, including their config defaults 

962 :rc:`figure.autolayout` and :rc:`figure.constrained_layout.use`. 

963 

964 **kwargs 

965 Additional keyword arguments are passed to the `.Figure` constructor. 

966 

967 Returns 

968 ------- 

969 `~matplotlib.figure.Figure` 

970 

971 Notes 

972 ----- 

973 A newly created figure is passed to the `~.FigureCanvasBase.new_manager` 

974 method or the `new_figure_manager` function provided by the current 

975 backend, which install a canvas and a manager on the figure. 

976 

977 Once this is done, :rc:`figure.hooks` are called, one at a time, on the 

978 figure; these hooks allow arbitrary customization of the figure (e.g., 

979 attaching callbacks) or of associated elements (e.g., modifying the 

980 toolbar). See :doc:`/gallery/user_interfaces/mplcvd` for an example of 

981 toolbar customization. 

982 

983 If you are creating many figures, make sure you explicitly call 

984 `.pyplot.close` on the figures you are not using, because this will 

985 enable pyplot to properly clean up the memory. 

986 

987 `~matplotlib.rcParams` defines the default values, which can be modified 

988 in the matplotlibrc file. 

989 """ 

990 allnums = get_fignums() 

991 

992 if isinstance(num, FigureBase): 

993 # type narrowed to `Figure | SubFigure` by combination of input and isinstance 

994 root_fig = num.get_figure(root=True) 

995 if root_fig.canvas.manager is None: 

996 raise ValueError("The passed figure is not managed by pyplot") 

997 elif (any(param is not None for param in [figsize, dpi, facecolor, edgecolor]) 

998 or not frameon or kwargs) and root_fig.canvas.manager.num in allnums: 

999 _api.warn_external( 

1000 "Ignoring specified arguments in this call because figure " 

1001 f"with num: {root_fig.canvas.manager.num} already exists") 

1002 _pylab_helpers.Gcf.set_active(root_fig.canvas.manager) 

1003 return root_fig 

1004 

1005 next_num = max(allnums) + 1 if allnums else 1 

1006 fig_label = '' 

1007 if num is None: 

1008 num = next_num 

1009 else: 

1010 if (any(param is not None for param in [figsize, dpi, facecolor, edgecolor]) 

1011 or not frameon or kwargs) and num in allnums: 

1012 _api.warn_external( 

1013 "Ignoring specified arguments in this call " 

1014 f"because figure with num: {num} already exists") 

1015 if isinstance(num, str): 

1016 fig_label = num 

1017 all_labels = get_figlabels() 

1018 if fig_label not in all_labels: 

1019 if fig_label == 'all': 

1020 _api.warn_external("close('all') closes all existing figures.") 

1021 num = next_num 

1022 else: 

1023 inum = all_labels.index(fig_label) 

1024 num = allnums[inum] 

1025 else: 

1026 num = int(num) # crude validation of num argument 

1027 

1028 # Type of "num" has narrowed to int, but mypy can't quite see it 

1029 manager = _pylab_helpers.Gcf.get_fig_manager(num) # type: ignore[arg-type] 

1030 if manager is None: 

1031 max_open_warning = rcParams['figure.max_open_warning'] 

1032 if len(allnums) == max_open_warning >= 1: 

1033 _api.warn_external( 

1034 f"More than {max_open_warning} figures have been opened. " 

1035 f"Figures created through the pyplot interface " 

1036 f"(`matplotlib.pyplot.figure`) are retained until explicitly " 

1037 f"closed and may consume too much memory. (To control this " 

1038 f"warning, see the rcParam `figure.max_open_warning`). " 

1039 f"Consider using `matplotlib.pyplot.close()`.", 

1040 RuntimeWarning) 

1041 

1042 manager = new_figure_manager( 

1043 num, figsize=figsize, dpi=dpi, 

1044 facecolor=facecolor, edgecolor=edgecolor, frameon=frameon, 

1045 FigureClass=FigureClass, **kwargs) 

1046 fig = manager.canvas.figure 

1047 if fig_label: 

1048 fig.set_label(fig_label) 

1049 

1050 for hookspecs in rcParams["figure.hooks"]: 

1051 module_name, dotted_name = hookspecs.split(":") 

1052 obj: Any = importlib.import_module(module_name) 

1053 for part in dotted_name.split("."): 

1054 obj = getattr(obj, part) 

1055 obj(fig) 

1056 

1057 _pylab_helpers.Gcf._set_new_active_manager(manager) 

1058 

1059 # make sure backends (inline) that we don't ship that expect this 

1060 # to be called in plotting commands to make the figure call show 

1061 # still work. There is probably a better way to do this in the 

1062 # FigureManager base class. 

1063 draw_if_interactive() 

1064 

1065 if _REPL_DISPLAYHOOK is _ReplDisplayHook.PLAIN: 

1066 fig.stale_callback = _auto_draw_if_interactive 

1067 

1068 if clear: 

1069 manager.canvas.figure.clear() 

1070 

1071 return manager.canvas.figure 

1072 

1073 

1074def _auto_draw_if_interactive(fig, val): 

1075 """ 

1076 An internal helper function for making sure that auto-redrawing 

1077 works as intended in the plain python repl. 

1078 

1079 Parameters 

1080 ---------- 

1081 fig : Figure 

1082 A figure object which is assumed to be associated with a canvas 

1083 """ 

1084 if (val and matplotlib.is_interactive() 

1085 and not fig.canvas.is_saving() 

1086 and not fig.canvas._is_idle_drawing): 

1087 # Some artists can mark themselves as stale in the middle of drawing 

1088 # (e.g. axes position & tick labels being computed at draw time), but 

1089 # this shouldn't trigger a redraw because the current redraw will 

1090 # already take them into account. 

1091 with fig.canvas._idle_draw_cntx(): 

1092 fig.canvas.draw_idle() 

1093

1095def gcf() -> Figure: 

1096 """ 

1097 Get the current figure. 

1098 

1099 If there is currently no figure on the pyplot figure stack, a new one is 

1100 created using `~.pyplot.figure()`. (To test whether there is currently a 

1101 figure on the pyplot figure stack, check whether `~.pyplot.get_fignums()` 

1102 is empty.) 

1103 """ 

1104 manager = _pylab_helpers.Gcf.get_active() 

1105 if manager is not None: 

1106 return manager.canvas.figure 

1107 else: 

1108 return figure()

1111def fignum_exists(num: int | str) -> bool: 

1112 """ 

1113 Return whether the figure with the given id exists. 

1114 

1115 Parameters 

1116 ---------- 

1117 num : int or str 

1118 A figure identifier. 

1119 

1120 Returns 

1121 ------- 

1122 bool 

1123 Whether or not a figure with id *num* exists. 

1124 """ 

1125 return ( 

1126 _pylab_helpers.Gcf.has_fignum(num) 

1127 if isinstance(num, int) 

1128 else num in get_figlabels() 

1129 ) 

1130

1132def get_fignums() -> list[int]: 

1133 """Return a list of existing figure numbers.""" 

1134 return sorted(_pylab_helpers.Gcf.figs)

1136 

1137def get_figlabels() -> list[Any]: 

1138 """Return a list of existing figure labels.""" 

1139 managers = _pylab_helpers.Gcf.get_all_fig_managers() 

1140 managers.sort(key=lambda m: m.num) 

1141 return [m.canvas.figure.get_label() for m in managers]

1144def get_current_fig_manager() -> FigureManagerBase | None: 

1145 """ 

1146 Return the figure manager of the current figure. 

1147 

1148 The figure manager is a container for the actual backend-depended window 

1149 that displays the figure on screen. 

1150 

1151 If no current figure exists, a new one is created, and its figure 

1152 manager is returned. 

1153 

1154 Returns 

1155 ------- 

1156 `.FigureManagerBase` or backend-dependent subclass thereof 

1157 """ 

1158 return gcf().canvas.manager

1170 

1171def close(fig: None | int | str | Figure | Literal["all"] = None) -> None: 

1172 """ 

1173 Close a figure window. 

1174 

1175 Parameters 

1176 ---------- 

1177 fig : None or int or str or `.Figure` 

1178 The figure to close. There are a number of ways to specify this: 

1179 

1180 - *None*: the current figure 

1181 - `.Figure`: the given `.Figure` instance 

1182 - ``int``: a figure number 

1183 - ``str``: a figure name 

1184 - 'all': all figures 

1185 

1186 """ 

1187 if fig is None: 

1188 manager = _pylab_helpers.Gcf.get_active() 

1189 if manager is None: 

1190 return 

1191 else: 

1192 _pylab_helpers.Gcf.destroy(manager) 

1193 elif fig == 'all': 

1194 _pylab_helpers.Gcf.destroy_all() 

1195 elif isinstance(fig, int): 

1196 _pylab_helpers.Gcf.destroy(fig) 

1197 elif hasattr(fig, 'int'): 

1198 # if we are dealing with a type UUID, we 

1199 # can use its integer representation 

1200 _pylab_helpers.Gcf.destroy(fig.int) 

1201 elif isinstance(fig, str): 

1202 all_labels = get_figlabels() 

1203 if fig in all_labels: 

1204 num = get_fignums()[all_labels.index(fig)] 

1205 _pylab_helpers.Gcf.destroy(num) 

1206 elif isinstance(fig, Figure): 

1207 _pylab_helpers.Gcf.destroy_fig(fig) 

1208 else: 

1209 raise TypeError("close() argument must be a Figure, an int, a string, " 

1210 "or None, not %s" % type(fig)) 

1211 

1212 

1213def clf() -> None: 

1214 """Clear the current figure.""" 

1215 gcf().clear()

1218def draw() -> None: 

1219 """ 

1220 Redraw the current figure. 

1221 

1222 This is used to update a figure that has been altered, but not 

1223 automatically re-drawn. If interactive mode is on (via `.ion()`), this 

1224 should be only rarely needed, but there may be ways to modify the state of 

1225 a figure without marking it as "stale". Please report these cases as bugs. 

1226 

1227 This is equivalent to calling ``fig.canvas.draw_idle()``, where ``fig`` is 

1228 the current figure. 

1229 

1230 See Also 

1231 -------- 

1232 .FigureCanvasBase.draw_idle 

1233 .FigureCanvasBase.draw 

1234 """ 

1235 gcf().canvas.draw_idle() 

1236

1238@_copy_docstring_and_deprecators(Figure.savefig) 

1239def savefig(*args, **kwargs) -> None: 

1240 fig = gcf() 

1241 # savefig default implementation has no return, so mypy is unhappy 

1242 # presumably this is here because subclasses can return? 

1243 res = fig.savefig(*args, **kwargs) # type: ignore[func-returns-value] 

1244 fig.canvas.draw_idle() # Need this if 'transparent=True', to reset colors. 

1245 return res

1260## Axes ## 

1261 

1262@_docstring.interpd 

1263def axes( 

1264 arg: None | tuple[float, float, float, float] = None, 

1265 **kwargs 

1266) -> matplotlib.axes.Axes: 

1267 """ 

1268 Add an Axes to the current figure and make it the current Axes. 

1269 

1270 Call signatures:: 

1271 

1272 plt.axes() 

1273 plt.axes(rect, projection=None, polar=False, **kwargs) 

1274 plt.axes(ax) 

1275 

1276 Parameters 

1277 ---------- 

1278 arg : None or 4-tuple 

1279 The exact behavior of this function depends on the type: 

1280 

1281 - *None*: A new full window Axes is added using 

1282 ``subplot(**kwargs)``. 

1283 - 4-tuple of floats *rect* = ``(left, bottom, width, height)``. 

1284 A new Axes is added with dimensions *rect* in normalized 

1285 (0, 1) units using `~.Figure.add_axes` on the current figure. 

1286 

1287 projection : {None, 'aitoff', 'hammer', 'lambert', 'mollweide', \ 

1288'polar', 'rectilinear', str}, optional 

1289 The projection type of the `~.axes.Axes`. *str* is the name of 

1290 a custom projection, see `~matplotlib.projections`. The default 

1291 None results in a 'rectilinear' projection. 

1292 

1293 polar : bool, default: False 

1294 If True, equivalent to projection='polar'. 

1295 

1296 sharex, sharey : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes`, optional 

1297 Share the x or y `~matplotlib.axis` with sharex and/or sharey. 

1298 The axis will have the same limits, ticks, and scale as the axis 

1299 of the shared Axes. 

1300 

1301 label : str 

1302 A label for the returned Axes. 

1303 

1304 Returns 

1305 ------- 

1306 `~.axes.Axes`, or a subclass of `~.axes.Axes` 

1307 The returned Axes class depends on the projection used. It is 

1308 `~.axes.Axes` if rectilinear projection is used and 

1309 `.projections.polar.PolarAxes` if polar projection is used. 

1310 

1311 Other Parameters 

1312 ---------------- 

1313 **kwargs 

1314 This method also takes the keyword arguments for 

1315 the returned Axes class. The keyword arguments for the 

1316 rectilinear Axes class `~.axes.Axes` can be found in 

1317 the following table but there might also be other keyword 

1318 arguments if another projection is used, see the actual Axes 

1319 class. 

1320 

1321 %(Axes:kwdoc)s 

1322 

1323 See Also 

1324 -------- 

1325 .Figure.add_axes 

1326 .pyplot.subplot 

1327 .Figure.add_subplot 

1328 .Figure.subplots 

1329 .pyplot.subplots 

1330 

1331 Examples 

1332 -------- 

1333 :: 

1334 

1335 # Creating a new full window Axes 

1336 plt.axes() 

1337 

1338 # Creating a new Axes with specified dimensions and a grey background 

1339 plt.axes((left, bottom, width, height), facecolor='grey') 

1340 """ 

1341 fig = gcf() 

1342 pos = kwargs.pop('position', None) 

1343 if arg is None: 

1344 if pos is None: 

1345 return fig.add_subplot(**kwargs) 

1346 else: 

1347 return fig.add_axes(pos, **kwargs) 

1348 else: 

1349 return fig.add_axes(arg, **kwargs) 

1350

1352def delaxes(ax: matplotlib.axes.Axes | None = None) -> None: 

1353 """ 

1354 Remove an `~.axes.Axes` (defaulting to the current Axes) from its figure. 

1355 """ 

1356 if ax is None: 

1357 ax = gca() 

1358 ax.remove()

1362 """ 

1363 Set the current Axes to *ax* and the current Figure to the parent of *ax*. 

1364 """ 

1365 # Mypy sees ax.figure as potentially None, 

1366 # but if you are calling this, it won't be None 

1367 # Additionally the slight difference between `Figure` and `FigureBase` mypy catches 

1368 fig = ax.get_figure(root=False)

1370 fig.sca(ax) # type: ignore[union-attr]

1379## More ways of creating Axes ## 

1380 

1381@_docstring.interpd 

1382def subplot(*args, **kwargs) -> Axes: 

1383 """ 

1384 Add an Axes to the current figure or retrieve an existing Axes. 

1385 

1386 This is a wrapper of `.Figure.add_subplot` which provides additional 

1387 behavior when working with the implicit API (see the notes section). 

1388 

1389 Call signatures:: 

1390 

1391 subplot(nrows, ncols, index, **kwargs) 

1392 subplot(pos, **kwargs) 

1393 subplot(**kwargs) 

1394 subplot(ax) 

1395 

1396 Parameters 

1397 ---------- 

1398 *args : int, (int, int, *index*), or `.SubplotSpec`, default: (1, 1, 1) 

1399 The position of the subplot described by one of 

1400 

1401 - Three integers (*nrows*, *ncols*, *index*). The subplot will take the 

1402 *index* position on a grid with *nrows* rows and *ncols* columns. 

1403 *index* starts at 1 in the upper left corner and increases to the 

1404 right. *index* can also be a two-tuple specifying the (*first*, 

1405 *last*) indices (1-based, and including *last*) of the subplot, e.g., 

1406 ``fig.add_subplot(3, 1, (1, 2))`` makes a subplot that spans the 

1407 upper 2/3 of the figure. 

1408 - A 3-digit integer. The digits are interpreted as if given separately 

1409 as three single-digit integers, i.e. ``fig.add_subplot(235)`` is the 

1410 same as ``fig.add_subplot(2, 3, 5)``. Note that this can only be used 

1411 if there are no more than 9 subplots. 

1412 - A `.SubplotSpec`. 

1413 

1414 projection : {None, 'aitoff', 'hammer', 'lambert', 'mollweide', \ 

1415'polar', 'rectilinear', str}, optional 

1416 The projection type of the subplot (`~.axes.Axes`). *str* is the name 

1417 of a custom projection, see `~matplotlib.projections`. The default 

1418 None results in a 'rectilinear' projection. 

1419 

1420 polar : bool, default: False 

1421 If True, equivalent to projection='polar'. 

1422 

1423 sharex, sharey : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes`, optional 

1424 Share the x or y `~matplotlib.axis` with sharex and/or sharey. The 

1425 axis will have the same limits, ticks, and scale as the axis of the 

1426 shared Axes. 

1427 

1428 label : str 

1429 A label for the returned Axes. 

1430 

1431 Returns 

1432 ------- 

1433 `~.axes.Axes` 

1434 

1435 The Axes of the subplot. The returned Axes can actually be an instance 

1436 of a subclass, such as `.projections.polar.PolarAxes` for polar 

1437 projections. 

1438 

1439 Other Parameters 

1440 ---------------- 

1441 **kwargs 

1442 This method also takes the keyword arguments for the returned Axes 

1443 base class; except for the *figure* argument. The keyword arguments 

1444 for the rectilinear base class `~.axes.Axes` can be found in 

1445 the following table but there might also be other keyword 

1446 arguments if another projection is used. 

1447 

1448 %(Axes:kwdoc)s 

1449 

1450 Notes 

1451 ----- 

1452 .. versionchanged:: 3.8 

1453 In versions prior to 3.8, any preexisting Axes that overlap with the new Axes 

1454 beyond sharing a boundary was deleted. Deletion does not happen in more 

1455 recent versions anymore. Use `.Axes.remove` explicitly if needed. 

1456 

1457 If you do not want this behavior, use the `.Figure.add_subplot` method 

1458 or the `.pyplot.axes` function instead. 

1459 

1460 If no *kwargs* are passed and there exists an Axes in the location 

1461 specified by *args* then that Axes will be returned rather than a new 

1462 Axes being created. 

1463 

1464 If *kwargs* are passed and there exists an Axes in the location 

1465 specified by *args*, the projection type is the same, and the 

1466 *kwargs* match with the existing Axes, then the existing Axes is 

1467 returned. Otherwise a new Axes is created with the specified 

1468 parameters. We save a reference to the *kwargs* which we use 

1469 for this comparison. If any of the values in *kwargs* are 

1470 mutable we will not detect the case where they are mutated. 

1471 In these cases we suggest using `.Figure.add_subplot` and the 

1472 explicit Axes API rather than the implicit pyplot API. 

1473 

1474 See Also 

1475 -------- 

1476 .Figure.add_subplot 

1477 .pyplot.subplots 

1478 .pyplot.axes 

1479 .Figure.subplots 

1480 

1481 Examples 

1482 -------- 

1483 :: 

1484 

1485 plt.subplot(221) 

1486 

1487 # equivalent but more general 

1488 ax1 = plt.subplot(2, 2, 1) 

1489 

1490 # add a subplot with no frame 

1491 ax2 = plt.subplot(222, frameon=False) 

1492 

1493 # add a polar subplot 

1494 plt.subplot(223, projection='polar') 

1495 

1496 # add a red subplot that shares the x-axis with ax1 

1497 plt.subplot(224, sharex=ax1, facecolor='red') 

1498 

1499 # delete ax2 from the figure 

1500 plt.delaxes(ax2) 

1501 

1502 # add ax2 to the figure again 

1503 plt.subplot(ax2) 

1504 

1505 # make the first Axes "current" again 

1506 plt.subplot(221) 

1507 

1508 """ 

1509 # Here we will only normalize `polar=True` vs `projection='polar'` and let 

1510 # downstream code deal with the rest. 

1511 unset = object() 

1512 projection = kwargs.get('projection', unset) 

1513 polar = kwargs.pop('polar', unset) 

1514 if polar is not unset and polar: 

1515 # if we got mixed messages from the user, raise 

1516 if projection is not unset and projection != 'polar': 

1517 raise ValueError( 

1518 f"polar={polar}, yet projection={projection!r}. " 

1519 "Only one of these arguments should be supplied." 

1520 ) 

1521 kwargs['projection'] = projection = 'polar' 

1522 

1523 # if subplot called without arguments, create subplot(1, 1, 1) 

1524 if len(args) == 0: 

1525 args = (1, 1, 1) 

1526 

1527 # This check was added because it is very easy to type subplot(1, 2, False) 

1528 # when subplots(1, 2, False) was intended (sharex=False, that is). In most 

1529 # cases, no error will ever occur, but mysterious behavior can result 

1530 # because what was intended to be the sharex argument is instead treated as 

1531 # a subplot index for subplot() 

1532 if len(args) >= 3 and isinstance(args[2], bool): 

1533 _api.warn_external("The subplot index argument to subplot() appears " 

1534 "to be a boolean. Did you intend to use " 

1535 "subplots()?") 

1536 # Check for nrows and ncols, which are not valid subplot args: 

1537 if 'nrows' in kwargs or 'ncols' in kwargs: 

1538 raise TypeError("subplot() got an unexpected keyword argument 'ncols' " 

1539 "and/or 'nrows'. Did you intend to call subplots()?") 

1540 

1541 fig = gcf() 

1542 

1543 # First, search for an existing subplot with a matching spec. 

1544 key = SubplotSpec._from_subplot_args(fig, args) 

1545 

1546 for ax in fig.axes: 

1547 # If we found an Axes at the position, we can reuse it if the user passed no 

1548 # kwargs or if the Axes class and kwargs are identical. 

1549 if (ax.get_subplotspec() == key 

1550 and (kwargs == {} 

1551 or (ax._projection_init 

1552 == fig._process_projection_requirements(**kwargs)))): 

1553 break 

1554 else: 

1555 # we have exhausted the known Axes and none match, make a new one! 

1556 ax = fig.add_subplot(*args, **kwargs) 

1557 

1558 fig.sca(ax) 

1559 

1560 return ax 

1561

1597@overload 

1598def subplots( 

1599 nrows: int = ..., 

1600 ncols: int = ..., 

1601 *, 

1602 sharex: bool | Literal["none", "all", "row", "col"] = ..., 

1603 sharey: bool | Literal["none", "all", "row", "col"] = ..., 

1604 squeeze: bool = ..., 

1605 width_ratios: Sequence[float] | None = ..., 

1606 height_ratios: Sequence[float] | None = ..., 

1607 subplot_kw: dict[str, Any] | None = ..., 

1608 gridspec_kw: dict[str, Any] | None = ..., 

1609 **fig_kw 

1610) -> tuple[Figure, Any]: 

1611 ... 

1612 

1613 

1614def subplots( 

1615 nrows: int = 1, ncols: int = 1, *, 

1616 sharex: bool | Literal["none", "all", "row", "col"] = False, 

1617 sharey: bool | Literal["none", "all", "row", "col"] = False, 

1618 squeeze: bool = True, 

1619 width_ratios: Sequence[float] | None = None, 

1620 height_ratios: Sequence[float] | None = None, 

1621 subplot_kw: dict[str, Any] | None = None, 

1622 gridspec_kw: dict[str, Any] | None = None, 

1623 **fig_kw 

1624) -> tuple[Figure, Any]: 

1625 """ 

1626 Create a figure and a set of subplots. 

1627 

1628 This utility wrapper makes it convenient to create common layouts of 

1629 subplots, including the enclosing figure object, in a single call. 

1630 

1631 Parameters 

1632 ---------- 

1633 nrows, ncols : int, default: 1 

1634 Number of rows/columns of the subplot grid. 

1635 

1636 sharex, sharey : bool or {'none', 'all', 'row', 'col'}, default: False 

1637 Controls sharing of properties among x (*sharex*) or y (*sharey*) 

1638 axes: 

1639 

1640 - True or 'all': x- or y-axis will be shared among all subplots. 

1641 - False or 'none': each subplot x- or y-axis will be independent. 

1642 - 'row': each subplot row will share an x- or y-axis. 

1643 - 'col': each subplot column will share an x- or y-axis. 

1644 

1645 When subplots have a shared x-axis along a column, only the x tick 

1646 labels of the bottom subplot are created. Similarly, when subplots 

1647 have a shared y-axis along a row, only the y tick labels of the first 

1648 column subplot are created. To later turn other subplots' ticklabels 

1649 on, use `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.tick_params`. 

1650 

1651 When subplots have a shared axis that has units, calling 

1652 `.Axis.set_units` will update each axis with the new units. 

1653 

1654 Note that it is not possible to unshare axes. 

1655 

1656 squeeze : bool, default: True 

1657 - If True, extra dimensions are squeezed out from the returned 

1658 array of `~matplotlib.axes.Axes`: 

1659 

1660 - if only one subplot is constructed (nrows=ncols=1), the 

1661 resulting single Axes object is returned as a scalar. 

1662 - for Nx1 or 1xM subplots, the returned object is a 1D numpy 

1663 object array of Axes objects. 

1664 - for NxM, subplots with N>1 and M>1 are returned as a 2D array. 

1665 

1666 - If False, no squeezing at all is done: the returned Axes object is 

1667 always a 2D array containing Axes instances, even if it ends up 

1668 being 1x1. 

1669 

1670 width_ratios : array-like of length *ncols*, optional 

1671 Defines the relative widths of the columns. Each column gets a 

1672 relative width of ``width_ratios[i] / sum(width_ratios)``. 

1673 If not given, all columns will have the same width. Equivalent 

1674 to ``gridspec_kw={'width_ratios': [...]}``. 

1675 

1676 height_ratios : array-like of length *nrows*, optional 

1677 Defines the relative heights of the rows. Each row gets a 

1678 relative height of ``height_ratios[i] / sum(height_ratios)``. 

1679 If not given, all rows will have the same height. Convenience 

1680 for ``gridspec_kw={'height_ratios': [...]}``. 

1681 

1682 subplot_kw : dict, optional 

1683 Dict with keywords passed to the 

1684 `~matplotlib.figure.Figure.add_subplot` call used to create each 

1685 subplot. 

1686 

1687 gridspec_kw : dict, optional 

1688 Dict with keywords passed to the `~matplotlib.gridspec.GridSpec` 

1689 constructor used to create the grid the subplots are placed on. 

1690 

1691 **fig_kw 

1692 All additional keyword arguments are passed to the 

1693 `.pyplot.figure` call. 

1694 

1695 Returns 

1696 ------- 

1697 fig : `.Figure` 

1698 

1699 ax : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes` or array of Axes 

1700 *ax* can be either a single `~.axes.Axes` object, or an array of Axes 

1701 objects if more than one subplot was created. The dimensions of the 

1702 resulting array can be controlled with the squeeze keyword, see above. 

1703 

1704 Typical idioms for handling the return value are:: 

1705 

1706 # using the variable ax for single a Axes 

1707 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

1708 

1709 # using the variable axs for multiple Axes 

1710 fig, axs = plt.subplots(2, 2) 

1711 

1712 # using tuple unpacking for multiple Axes 

1713 fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2) 

1714 fig, ((ax1, ax2), (ax3, ax4)) = plt.subplots(2, 2) 

1715 

1716 The names ``ax`` and pluralized ``axs`` are preferred over ``axes`` 

1717 because for the latter it's not clear if it refers to a single 

1718 `~.axes.Axes` instance or a collection of these. 

1719 

1720 See Also 

1721 -------- 

1722 .pyplot.figure 

1723 .pyplot.subplot 

1724 .pyplot.axes 

1725 .Figure.subplots 

1726 .Figure.add_subplot 

1727 

1728 Examples 

1729 -------- 

1730 :: 

1731 

1732 # First create some toy data: 

1733 x = np.linspace(0, 2*np.pi, 400) 

1734 y = np.sin(x**2) 

1735 

1736 # Create just a figure and only one subplot 

1737 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

1738 ax.plot(x, y) 

1739 ax.set_title('Simple plot') 

1740 

1741 # Create two subplots and unpack the output array immediately 

1742 f, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, sharey=True) 

1743 ax1.plot(x, y) 

1744 ax1.set_title('Sharing Y axis') 

1745 ax2.scatter(x, y) 

1746 

1747 # Create four polar Axes and access them through the returned array 

1748 fig, axs = plt.subplots(2, 2, subplot_kw=dict(projection="polar")) 

1749 axs[0, 0].plot(x, y) 

1750 axs[1, 1].scatter(x, y) 

1751 

1752 # Share a X axis with each column of subplots 

1753 plt.subplots(2, 2, sharex='col') 

1754 

1755 # Share a Y axis with each row of subplots 

1756 plt.subplots(2, 2, sharey='row') 

1757 

1758 # Share both X and Y axes with all subplots 

1759 plt.subplots(2, 2, sharex='all', sharey='all') 

1760 

1761 # Note that this is the same as 

1762 plt.subplots(2, 2, sharex=True, sharey=True) 

1763 

1764 # Create figure number 10 with a single subplot 

1765 # and clears it if it already exists. 

1766 fig, ax = plt.subplots(num=10, clear=True) 

1767 

1768 """ 

1769 fig = figure(**fig_kw) 

1770 axs = fig.subplots(nrows=nrows, ncols=ncols, sharex=sharex, sharey=sharey, 

1771 squeeze=squeeze, subplot_kw=subplot_kw, 

1772 gridspec_kw=gridspec_kw, height_ratios=height_ratios, 

1773 width_ratios=width_ratios) 

1774 return fig, axs 

1775

1824 

1825def subplot_mosaic( 

1826 mosaic: str | list[HashableList[_T]] | list[HashableList[Hashable]], 

1827 *, 

1828 sharex: bool = False, 

1829 sharey: bool = False, 

1830 width_ratios: ArrayLike | None = None, 

1831 height_ratios: ArrayLike | None = None, 

1832 empty_sentinel: Any = '.', 

1833 subplot_kw: dict[str, Any] | None = None, 

1834 gridspec_kw: dict[str, Any] | None = None, 

1835 per_subplot_kw: dict[str | tuple[str, ...], dict[str, Any]] | 

1836 dict[_T | tuple[_T, ...], dict[str, Any]] | 

1837 dict[Hashable | tuple[Hashable, ...], dict[str, Any]] | None = None, 

1838 **fig_kw: Any 

1839) -> tuple[Figure, dict[str, matplotlib.axes.Axes]] | \ 

1840 tuple[Figure, dict[_T, matplotlib.axes.Axes]] | \ 

1841 tuple[Figure, dict[Hashable, matplotlib.axes.Axes]]: 

1842 """ 

1843 Build a layout of Axes based on ASCII art or nested lists. 

1844 

1845 This is a helper function to build complex GridSpec layouts visually. 

1846 

1847 See :ref:`mosaic` 

1848 for an example and full API documentation 

1849 

1850 Parameters 

1851 ---------- 

1852 mosaic : list of list of {hashable or nested} or str 

1853 

1854 A visual layout of how you want your Axes to be arranged 

1855 labeled as strings. For example :: 

1856 

1857 x = [['A panel', 'A panel', 'edge'], 

1858 ['C panel', '.', 'edge']] 

1859 

1860 produces 4 Axes: 

1861 

1862 - 'A panel' which is 1 row high and spans the first two columns 

1863 - 'edge' which is 2 rows high and is on the right edge 

1864 - 'C panel' which in 1 row and 1 column wide in the bottom left 

1865 - a blank space 1 row and 1 column wide in the bottom center 

1866 

1867 Any of the entries in the layout can be a list of lists 

1868 of the same form to create nested layouts. 

1869 

1870 If input is a str, then it must be of the form :: 

1871 

1872 ''' 

1873 AAE 

1874 C.E 

1875 ''' 

1876 

1877 where each character is a column and each line is a row. 

1878 This only allows only single character Axes labels and does 

1879 not allow nesting but is very terse. 

1880 

1881 sharex, sharey : bool, default: False 

1882 If True, the x-axis (*sharex*) or y-axis (*sharey*) will be shared 

1883 among all subplots. In that case, tick label visibility and axis units 

1884 behave as for `subplots`. If False, each subplot's x- or y-axis will 

1885 be independent. 

1886 

1887 width_ratios : array-like of length *ncols*, optional 

1888 Defines the relative widths of the columns. Each column gets a 

1889 relative width of ``width_ratios[i] / sum(width_ratios)``. 

1890 If not given, all columns will have the same width. Convenience 

1891 for ``gridspec_kw={'width_ratios': [...]}``. 

1892 

1893 height_ratios : array-like of length *nrows*, optional 

1894 Defines the relative heights of the rows. Each row gets a 

1895 relative height of ``height_ratios[i] / sum(height_ratios)``. 

1896 If not given, all rows will have the same height. Convenience 

1897 for ``gridspec_kw={'height_ratios': [...]}``. 

1898 

1899 empty_sentinel : object, optional 

1900 Entry in the layout to mean "leave this space empty". Defaults 

1901 to ``'.'``. Note, if *layout* is a string, it is processed via 

1902 `inspect.cleandoc` to remove leading white space, which may 

1903 interfere with using white-space as the empty sentinel. 

1904 

1905 subplot_kw : dict, optional 

1906 Dictionary with keywords passed to the `.Figure.add_subplot` call 

1907 used to create each subplot. These values may be overridden by 

1908 values in *per_subplot_kw*. 

1909 

1910 per_subplot_kw : dict, optional 

1911 A dictionary mapping the Axes identifiers or tuples of identifiers 

1912 to a dictionary of keyword arguments to be passed to the 

1913 `.Figure.add_subplot` call used to create each subplot. The values 

1914 in these dictionaries have precedence over the values in 

1915 *subplot_kw*. 

1916 

1917 If *mosaic* is a string, and thus all keys are single characters, 

1918 it is possible to use a single string instead of a tuple as keys; 

1919 i.e. ``"AB"`` is equivalent to ``("A", "B")``. 

1920 

1921 .. versionadded:: 3.7 

1922 

1923 gridspec_kw : dict, optional 

1924 Dictionary with keywords passed to the `.GridSpec` constructor used 

1925 to create the grid the subplots are placed on. 

1926 

1927 **fig_kw 

1928 All additional keyword arguments are passed to the 

1929 `.pyplot.figure` call. 

1930 

1931 Returns 

1932 ------- 

1933 fig : `.Figure` 

1934 The new figure 

1935 

1936 dict[label, Axes] 

1937 A dictionary mapping the labels to the Axes objects. The order of 

1938 the Axes is left-to-right and top-to-bottom of their position in the 

1939 total layout. 

1940 

1941 """ 

1942 fig = figure(**fig_kw) 

1943 ax_dict = fig.subplot_mosaic( # type: ignore[misc] 

1944 mosaic, # type: ignore[arg-type] 

1945 sharex=sharex, sharey=sharey, 

1946 height_ratios=height_ratios, width_ratios=width_ratios, 

1947 subplot_kw=subplot_kw, gridspec_kw=gridspec_kw, 

1948 empty_sentinel=empty_sentinel, 

1949 per_subplot_kw=per_subplot_kw, # type: ignore[arg-type] 

1950 ) 

1951 return fig, ax_dict 

1952

1954def subplot2grid( 

1955 shape: tuple[int, int], loc: tuple[int, int], 

1956 rowspan: int = 1, colspan: int = 1, 

1957 fig: Figure | None = None, 

1958 **kwargs 

1959) -> matplotlib.axes.Axes: 

1960 """ 

1961 Create a subplot at a specific location inside a regular grid. 

1962 

1963 Parameters 

1964 ---------- 

1965 shape : (int, int) 

1966 Number of rows and of columns of the grid in which to place axis. 

1967 loc : (int, int) 

1968 Row number and column number of the axis location within the grid. 

1969 rowspan : int, default: 1 

1970 Number of rows for the axis to span downwards. 

1971 colspan : int, default: 1 

1972 Number of columns for the axis to span to the right. 

1973 fig : `.Figure`, optional 

1974 Figure to place the subplot in. Defaults to the current figure. 

1975 **kwargs 

1976 Additional keyword arguments are handed to `~.Figure.add_subplot`. 

1977 

1978 Returns 

1979 ------- 

1980 `~.axes.Axes` 

1981 

1982 The Axes of the subplot. The returned Axes can actually be an instance 

1983 of a subclass, such as `.projections.polar.PolarAxes` for polar 

1984 projections. 

1985 

1986 Notes 

1987 ----- 

1988 The following call :: 

1989 

1990 ax = subplot2grid((nrows, ncols), (row, col), rowspan, colspan) 

1991 

1992 is identical to :: 

1993 

1994 fig = gcf() 

1995 gs = fig.add_gridspec(nrows, ncols) 

1996 ax = fig.add_subplot(gs[row:row+rowspan, col:col+colspan]) 

1997 """ 

1998 if fig is None: 

1999 fig = gcf() 

2000 rows, cols = shape 

2001 gs = GridSpec._check_gridspec_exists(fig, rows, cols) 

2002 subplotspec = gs.new_subplotspec(loc, rowspan=rowspan, colspan=colspan) 

2003 return fig.add_subplot(subplotspec, **kwargs)

2010 on the right. 

2011 

2012 Examples 

2013 -------- 

2014 :doc:`/gallery/subplots_axes_and_figures/two_scales` 

2015 """

2019 return ax1

2038def subplot_tool(targetfig: Figure | None = None) -> SubplotTool | None: 

2039 """ 

2040 Launch a subplot tool window for a figure. 

2041 

2042 Returns 

2043 ------- 

2044 `matplotlib.widgets.SubplotTool` 

2045 """ 

2046 if targetfig is None: 

2047 targetfig = gcf() 

2048 tb = targetfig.canvas.manager.toolbar # type: ignore[union-attr] 

2049 if hasattr(tb, "configure_subplots"): # toolbar2 

2050 from matplotlib.backend_bases import NavigationToolbar2 

2051 return cast(NavigationToolbar2, tb).configure_subplots() 

2052 elif hasattr(tb, "trigger_tool"): # toolmanager 

2053 from matplotlib.backend_bases import ToolContainerBase 

2054 cast(ToolContainerBase, tb).trigger_tool("subplots") 

2055 return None 

2056 else: 

2057 raise ValueError("subplot_tool can only be launched for figures with " 

2058 "an associated toolbar")

2073 :meth:`matplotlib.axes.Axes.set_frame_on` 

2074 :meth:`matplotlib.axes.Axes.get_frame_on` 

2075 """ 

2076 ax = gca() 

2077 if on is None: 

2078 on = not ax.get_frame_on() 

2079 ax.set_frame_on(on)

2084def xlim(*args, **kwargs) -> tuple[float, float]: 

2085 """ 

2086 Get or set the x limits of the current Axes. 

2087 

2088 Call signatures:: 

2089 

2090 left, right = xlim() # return the current xlim 

2091 xlim((left, right)) # set the xlim to left, right 

2092 xlim(left, right) # set the xlim to left, right 

2093 

2094 If you do not specify args, you can pass *left* or *right* as kwargs, 

2095 i.e.:: 

2096 

2097 xlim(right=3) # adjust the right leaving left unchanged 

2098 xlim(left=1) # adjust the left leaving right unchanged 

2099 

2100 Setting limits turns autoscaling off for the x-axis. 

2101 

2102 Returns 

2103 ------- 

2104 left, right 

2105 A tuple of the new x-axis limits. 

2106 

2107 Notes 

2108 ----- 

2109 Calling this function with no arguments (e.g. ``xlim()``) is the pyplot 

2110 equivalent of calling `~.Axes.get_xlim` on the current Axes. 

2111 Calling this function with arguments is the pyplot equivalent of calling 

2112 `~.Axes.set_xlim` on the current Axes. All arguments are passed though. 

2113 """ 

2114 ax = gca() 

2115 if not args and not kwargs: 

2116 return ax.get_xlim() 

2117 ret = ax.set_xlim(*args, **kwargs) 

2118 return ret 

2119

2121def ylim(*args, **kwargs) -> tuple[float, float]: 

2122 """ 

2123 Get or set the y-limits of the current Axes. 

2124 

2125 Call signatures::

2127 bottom, top = ylim() # return the current ylim 

2128 ylim((bottom, top)) # set the ylim to bottom, top 

2129 ylim(bottom, top) # set the ylim to bottom, top 

2130 

2131 If you do not specify args, you can alternatively pass *bottom* or 

2132 *top* as kwargs, i.e.:: 

2133 

2134 ylim(top=3) # adjust the top leaving bottom unchanged 

2135 ylim(bottom=1) # adjust the bottom leaving top unchanged 

2136 

2137 Setting limits turns autoscaling off for the y-axis. 

2138 

2139 Returns 

2140 ------- 

2141 bottom, top 

2142 A tuple of the new y-axis limits. 

2143 

2144 Notes 

2145 ----- 

2146 Calling this function with no arguments (e.g. ``ylim()``) is the pyplot 

2147 equivalent of calling `~.Axes.get_ylim` on the current Axes. 

2148 Calling this function with arguments is the pyplot equivalent of calling 

2149 `~.Axes.set_ylim` on the current Axes. All arguments are passed though. 

2150 """ 

2151 ax = gca() 

2152 if not args and not kwargs: 

2153 return ax.get_ylim() 

2154 ret = ax.set_ylim(*args, **kwargs) 

2155 return ret

2158def xticks( 

2159 ticks: ArrayLike | None = None, 

2160 labels: Sequence[str] | None = None, 

2161 *, 

2162 minor: bool = False, 

2163 **kwargs 

2164) -> tuple[list[Tick] | np.ndarray, list[Text]]: 

2165 """ 

2166 Get or set the current tick locations and labels of the x-axis. 

2167 

2168 Pass no arguments to return the current values without modifying them. 

2169 

2170 Parameters 

2171 ---------- 

2172 ticks : array-like, optional 

2173 The list of xtick locations. Passing an empty list removes all xticks. 

2174 labels : array-like, optional 

2175 The labels to place at the given *ticks* locations. This argument can 

2176 only be passed if *ticks* is passed as well. 

2177 minor : bool, default: False 

2178 If ``False``, get/set the major ticks/labels; if ``True``, the minor 

2179 ticks/labels. 

2180 **kwargs 

2181 `.Text` properties can be used to control the appearance of the labels. 

2182 

2183 .. warning:: 

2184 

2185 This only sets the properties of the current ticks, which is 

2186 only sufficient if you either pass *ticks*, resulting in a 

2187 fixed list of ticks, or if the plot is static. 

2188 

2189 Ticks are not guaranteed to be persistent. Various operations 

2190 can create, delete and modify the Tick instances. There is an 

2191 imminent risk that these settings can get lost if you work on 

2192 the figure further (including also panning/zooming on a 

2193 displayed figure). 

2194 

2195 Use `~.pyplot.tick_params` instead if possible. 

2196 

2197 

2198 Returns 

2199 ------- 

2200 locs 

2201 The list of xtick locations. 

2202 labels 

2203 The list of xlabel `.Text` objects. 

2204 

2205 Notes 

2206 ----- 

2207 Calling this function with no arguments (e.g. ``xticks()``) is the pyplot 

2208 equivalent of calling `~.Axes.get_xticks` and `~.Axes.get_xticklabels` on 

2209 the current Axes. 

2210 Calling this function with arguments is the pyplot equivalent of calling 

2211 `~.Axes.set_xticks` and `~.Axes.set_xticklabels` on the current Axes. 

2212 

2213 Examples 

2214 -------- 

2215 >>> locs, labels = xticks() # Get the current locations and labels. 

2216 >>> xticks(np.arange(0, 1, step=0.2)) # Set label locations. 

2217 >>> xticks(np.arange(3), ['Tom', 'Dick', 'Sue']) # Set text labels. 

2218 >>> xticks([0, 1, 2], ['January', 'February', 'March'], 

2219 ... rotation=20) # Set text labels and properties. 

2220 >>> xticks([]) # Disable xticks. 

2221 """ 

2222 ax = gca() 

2223 

2224 locs: list[Tick] | np.ndarray 

2225 if ticks is None: 

2226 locs = ax.get_xticks(minor=minor) 

2227 if labels is not None: 

2228 raise TypeError("xticks(): Parameter 'labels' can't be set " 

2229 "without setting 'ticks'") 

2230 else: 

2231 locs = ax.set_xticks(ticks, minor=minor) 

2232 

2233 labels_out: list[Text] = [] 

2234 if labels is None: 

2235 labels_out = ax.get_xticklabels(minor=minor) 

2236 for l in labels_out: 

2237 l._internal_update(kwargs) 

2238 else: 

2239 labels_out = ax.set_xticklabels(labels, minor=minor, **kwargs) 

2240 

2241 return locs, labels_out 

2242

2245 ticks: ArrayLike | None = None,

2329def rgrids( 

2330 radii: ArrayLike | None = None, 

2331 labels: Sequence[str | Text] | None = None, 

2332 angle: float | None = None, 

2333 fmt: str | None = None, 

2334 **kwargs 

2335) -> tuple[list[Line2D], list[Text]]: 

2336 """ 

2337 Get or set the radial gridlines on the current polar plot. 

2338 

2339 Call signatures:: 

2340 

2341 lines, labels = rgrids() 

2342 lines, labels = rgrids(radii, labels=None, angle=22.5, fmt=None, **kwargs) 

2343 

2344 When called with no arguments, `.rgrids` simply returns the tuple 

2345 (*lines*, *labels*). When called with arguments, the labels will 

2346 appear at the specified radial distances and angle. 

2347 

2348 Parameters 

2349 ---------- 

2350 radii : tuple with floats 

2351 The radii for the radial gridlines 

2352 

2353 labels : tuple with strings or None 

2354 The labels to use at each radial gridline. The 

2355 `matplotlib.ticker.ScalarFormatter` will be used if None. 

2356 

2357 angle : float 

2358 The angular position of the radius labels in degrees. 

2359 

2360 fmt : str or None 

2361 Format string used in `matplotlib.ticker.FormatStrFormatter`. 

2362 For example '%f'. 

2363 

2364 Returns 

2365 ------- 

2366 lines : list of `.lines.Line2D` 

2367 The radial gridlines. 

2368 

2369 labels : list of `.text.Text` 

2370 The tick labels. 

2371 

2372 Other Parameters 

2373 ---------------- 

2374 **kwargs 

2375 *kwargs* are optional `.Text` properties for the labels. 

2376 

2377 See Also 

2378 -------- 

2379 .pyplot.thetagrids 

2380 .projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_rgrids 

2381 .Axis.get_gridlines 

2382 .Axis.get_ticklabels 

2383 

2384 Examples 

2385 -------- 

2386 :: 

2387 

2388 # set the locations of the radial gridlines 

2389 lines, labels = rgrids( (0.25, 0.5, 1.0) ) 

2390 

2391 # set the locations and labels of the radial gridlines 

2392 lines, labels = rgrids( (0.25, 0.5, 1.0), ('Tom', 'Dick', 'Harry' )) 

2393 """ 

2394 ax = gca() 

2395 if not isinstance(ax, PolarAxes): 

2396 raise RuntimeError('rgrids only defined for polar Axes') 

2397 if all(p is None for p in [radii, labels, angle, fmt]) and not kwargs: 

2398 lines_out: list[Line2D] = ax.yaxis.get_gridlines() 

2399 labels_out: list[Text] = ax.yaxis.get_ticklabels() 

2400 elif radii is None: 

2401 raise TypeError("'radii' cannot be None when other parameters are passed") 

2402 else: 

2403 lines_out, labels_out = ax.set_rgrids( 

2404 radii, labels=labels, angle=angle, fmt=fmt, **kwargs) 

2405 return lines_out, labels_out

2408def thetagrids( 

2409 angles: ArrayLike | None = None, 

2410 labels: Sequence[str | Text] | None = None, 

2411 fmt: str | None = None, 

2412 **kwargs 

2413) -> tuple[list[Line2D], list[Text]]: 

2414 """ 

2415 Get or set the theta gridlines on the current polar plot. 

2416 

2417 Call signatures:: 

2418 

2419 lines, labels = thetagrids() 

2420 lines, labels = thetagrids(angles, labels=None, fmt=None, **kwargs) 

2421 

2422 When called with no arguments, `.thetagrids` simply returns the tuple 

2423 (*lines*, *labels*). When called with arguments, the labels will 

2424 appear at the specified angles. 

2425 

2426 Parameters 

2427 ---------- 

2428 angles : tuple with floats, degrees 

2429 The angles of the theta gridlines. 

2430 

2431 labels : tuple with strings or None 

2432 The labels to use at each radial gridline. The 

2433 `.projections.polar.ThetaFormatter` will be used if None. 

2434 

2435 fmt : str or None 

2436 Format string used in `matplotlib.ticker.FormatStrFormatter`. 

2437 For example '%f'. Note that the angle in radians will be used. 

2438 

2439 Returns 

2440 ------- 

2441 lines : list of `.lines.Line2D` 

2442 The theta gridlines. 

2443 

2444 labels : list of `.text.Text` 

2445 The tick labels. 

2446 

2447 Other Parameters 

2448 ---------------- 

2449 **kwargs 

2450 *kwargs* are optional `.Text` properties for the labels. 

2451 

2452 See Also 

2453 -------- 

2454 .pyplot.rgrids 

2455 .projections.polar.PolarAxes.set_thetagrids 

2456 .Axis.get_gridlines 

2457 .Axis.get_ticklabels 

2458 

2459 Examples 

2460 -------- 

2461 :: 

2462 

2463 # set the locations of the angular gridlines 

2464 lines, labels = thetagrids(range(45, 360, 90)) 

2465 

2466 # set the locations and labels of the angular gridlines 

2467 lines, labels = thetagrids(range(45, 360, 90), ('NE', 'NW', 'SW', 'SE')) 

2468 """ 

2469 ax = gca() 

2470 if not isinstance(ax, PolarAxes): 

2471 raise RuntimeError('thetagrids only defined for polar Axes') 

2472 if all(param is None for param in [angles, labels, fmt]) and not kwargs: 

2473 lines_out: list[Line2D] = ax.xaxis.get_ticklines() 

2474 labels_out: list[Text] = ax.xaxis.get_ticklabels() 

2475 elif angles is None: 

2476 raise TypeError("'angles' cannot be None when other parameters are passed") 

2477 else: 

2478 lines_out, labels_out = ax.set_thetagrids(angles, 

2479 labels=labels, fmt=fmt, 

2480 **kwargs) 

2481 return lines_out, labels_out

2495 

2496def _get_pyplot_commands() -> list[str]: 

2497 # This works by searching for all functions in this module and removing 

2498 # a few hard-coded exclusions, as well as all of the colormap-setting 

2499 # functions, and anything marked as private with a preceding underscore. 

2500 exclude = {'colormaps', 'colors', 'get_plot_commands', *colormaps} 

2501 this_module = inspect.getmodule(get_plot_commands) 

2502 return sorted( 

2503 name for name, obj in globals().items() 

2504 if not name.startswith('_') and name not in exclude 

2505 and inspect.isfunction(obj) 

2506 and inspect.getmodule(obj) is this_module) 

2507 

2508 

2509## Plotting part 1: manually generated functions and wrappers ##

2512@_copy_docstring_and_deprecators(Figure.colorbar) 

2513def colorbar( 

2514 mappable: ScalarMappable | ColorizingArtist | None = None, 

2515 cax: matplotlib.axes.Axes | None = None, 

2516 ax: matplotlib.axes.Axes | Iterable[matplotlib.axes.Axes] | None = None, 

2517 **kwargs 

2518) -> Colorbar: 

2519 if mappable is None: 

2520 mappable = gci() 

2521 if mappable is None: 

2522 raise RuntimeError('No mappable was found to use for colorbar ' 

2523 'creation. First define a mappable such as ' 

2524 'an image (with imshow) or a contour set (' 

2525 'with contourf).') 

2526 ret = gcf().colorbar(mappable, cax=cax, ax=ax, **kwargs) 

2527 return ret

2530def clim(vmin: float | None = None, vmax: float | None = None) -> None: 

2531 """ 

2532 Set the color limits of the current image. 

2533 

2534 If either *vmin* or *vmax* is None, the image min/max respectively 

2535 will be used for color scaling. 

2536 

2537 If you want to set the clim of multiple images, use 

2538 `~.ScalarMappable.set_clim` on every image, for example:: 

2539 

2540 for im in gca().get_images(): 

2541 im.set_clim(0, 0.5) 

2542 

2543 """ 

2544 im = gci() 

2545 if im is None: 

2546 raise RuntimeError('You must first define an image, e.g., with imshow') 

2547 

2548 im.set_clim(vmin, vmax)

2550 

2551def get_cmap(name: Colormap | str | None = None, lut: int | None = None) -> Colormap: 

2552 """ 

2553 Get a colormap instance, defaulting to rc values if *name* is None. 

2554 

2555 Parameters 

2556 ---------- 

2557 name : `~matplotlib.colors.Colormap` or str or None, default: None 

2558 If a `.Colormap` instance, it will be returned. Otherwise, the name of 

2559 a colormap known to Matplotlib, which will be resampled by *lut*. The 

2560 default, None, means :rc:`image.cmap`. 

2561 lut : int or None, default: None 

2562 If *name* is not already a Colormap instance and *lut* is not None, the 

2563 colormap will be resampled to have *lut* entries in the lookup table. 

2564 

2565 Returns 

2566 ------- 

2567 Colormap 

2568 """ 

2569 if name is None: 

2570 name = rcParams['image.cmap'] 

2571 if isinstance(name, Colormap): 

2572 return name 

2573 _api.check_in_list(sorted(_colormaps), name=name) 

2574 if lut is None: 

2575 return _colormaps[name] 

2576 else: 

2577 return _colormaps[name].resampled(lut) 

2578 

2579 

2580def set_cmap(cmap: Colormap | str) -> None: 

2581 """ 

2582 Set the default colormap, and applies it to the current image if any. 

2583 

2584 Parameters 

2585 ---------- 

2586 cmap : `~matplotlib.colors.Colormap` or str 

2587 A colormap instance or the name of a registered colormap. 

2588 

2589 See Also 

2590 -------- 

2591 colormaps 

2592 get_cmap 

2593 """ 

2594 cmap = get_cmap(cmap) 

2595 

2596 rc('image', cmap=cmap.name) 

2597 im = gci() 

2598 

2599 if im is not None: 

2600 im.set_cmap(cmap)
