2616 

2617def matshow(A: ArrayLike, fignum: None | int = None, **kwargs) -> AxesImage: 

2618 """ 

2619 Display a 2D array as a matrix in a new figure window. 

2620 

2621 The origin is set at the upper left hand corner. 

2622 The indexing is ``(row, column)`` so that the first index runs vertically 

2623 and the second index runs horizontally in the figure: 

2624 

2625 .. code-block:: none 

2626 

2627 A[0, 0] ⋯ A[0, M-1] 

2628 ⋮ ⋮ 

2629 A[N-1, 0] ⋯ A[N-1, M-1] 

2630 

2631 The aspect ratio of the figure window is that of the array, 

2632 unless this would make an excessively short or narrow figure. 

2633 

2634 Tick labels for the xaxis are placed on top. 

2635 

2636 Parameters 

2637 ---------- 

2638 A : 2D array-like 

2639 The matrix to be displayed. 

2640 

2641 fignum : None or int 

2642 If *None*, create a new, appropriately sized figure window. 

2643 

2644 If 0, use the current Axes (creating one if there is none, without ever 

2645 adjusting the figure size). 

2646 

2647 Otherwise, create a new Axes on the figure with the given number 

2648 (creating it at the appropriate size if it does not exist, but not 

2649 adjusting the figure size otherwise). Note that this will be drawn on 

2650 top of any preexisting Axes on the figure. 

2651 

2652 Returns 

2653 ------- 

2654 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage` 

2655 

2656 Other Parameters 

2657 ---------------- 

2658 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.imshow` arguments 

2659 

2660 """ 

2661 A = np.asanyarray(A) 

2662 if fignum == 0: 

2663 ax = gca() 

2664 else: 

2665 if fignum is not None and fignum_exists(fignum): 

2666 # Do not try to set a figure size. 

2667 figsize = None 

2668 else: 

2669 # Extract actual aspect ratio of array and make appropriately sized figure. 

2670 figsize = figaspect(A) 

2671 fig = figure(fignum, figsize=figsize) 

2672 ax = fig.add_axes((0.15, 0.09, 0.775, 0.775)) 

2673 im = ax.matshow(A, **kwargs) 

2674 sci(im) 

2675 return im 

2676 

2677 

2678def polar(*args, **kwargs) -> list[Line2D]: 

2679 """ 

2680 Make a polar plot. 

2681 

2682 call signature:: 

2683 

2684 polar(theta, r, [fmt], **kwargs) 

2685 

2686 This is a convenience wrapper around `.pyplot.plot`. It ensures that the 

2687 current Axes is polar (or creates one if needed) and then passes all parameters 

2688 to ``.pyplot.plot``. 

2689 

2690 .. note:: 

2691 When making polar plots using the :ref:`pyplot API <pyplot_interface>`, 

2692 ``polar()`` should typically be the first command because that makes sure 

2693 a polar Axes is created. Using other commands such as ``plt.title()`` 

2694 before this can lead to the implicit creation of a rectangular Axes, in which 

2695 case a subsequent ``polar()`` call will fail. 

2696 """ 

2697 # If an axis already exists, check if it has a polar projection 

2698 if gcf().get_axes(): 

2699 ax = gca() 

2700 if not isinstance(ax, PolarAxes): 

2701 _api.warn_deprecated( 

2702 "3.10", 

2703 message="There exists a non-polar current Axes. Therefore, the " 

2704 "resulting plot from 'polar()' is non-polar. You likely " 

2705 "should call 'polar()' before any other pyplot plotting " 

2706 "commands. " 

2707 "Support for this scenario is deprecated in %(since)s and " 

2708 "will raise an error in %(removal)s" 

2709 ) 

2710 else: 

2711 ax = axes(projection="polar") 

2712 return ax.plot(*args, **kwargs) 

2713 

2714 

2715# If rcParams['backend_fallback'] is true, and an interactive backend is 

2716# requested, ignore rcParams['backend'] and force selection of a backend that 

2717# is compatible with the current running interactive framework. 

2718if (rcParams["backend_fallback"] 

2719 and rcParams._get_backend_or_none() in ( # type: ignore[attr-defined] 

2720 set(backend_registry.list_builtin(BackendFilter.INTERACTIVE)) - 

2721 {'webagg', 'nbagg'}) 

2722 and cbook._get_running_interactive_framework()): 

2723 rcParams._set("backend", rcsetup._auto_backend_sentinel) 

2724 

2725# fmt: on 

2726 

2727################# REMAINING CONTENT GENERATED BY boilerplate.py ##############
